I first check that the sizes are the same before doing a uni-
directional "contains". That should take care of the situation where 
one collection is larger than the other. But, you bring up another 
point. How can I tell how many times an element appears in a 
collection, such as a map? If multiple elements hash to the same 
value is there a way to tell that their are multiple elements for 
that hashvalue? The size() method will only tell me how many hash 
values there are. Not how many total elements.

--- In junit@y..., "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@d...> wrote:
> > Thanks for the info. Actually, by the time I read your reply I 
had 
> > already written something similar to the code you directed me to. 
I 
> > looped through one collection and then determined if each item in 
it 
> > was in the other collection using the "contains" method. Sounds 
like 
> > JUnit could use another overloaded version of assertEquals.
> 
> Careful: this only checks "subcollection". You'd have to do it in 
each 
> direction *and* check size *and* check elements appearing multiple 
times, to 
> be sure.
>
